hints_html: What does this region look like? How can you find the area of such a region?
hints_latex:
What does this region look like? How can you find the area of such a
region?
hints_raw: What does this region look like? How can you find the area of such a region?
sols_html:
First, we sketch each of the three curves to see what is the region that we are talking about.

We will need to find the coordinates of points A and B which are the intersection of curves. For A we have

\[\begin{aligned} -x &= - \frac{2}{x}\\ x^2 &= 2\\ x &= \pm \sqrt{2}\end{aligned}\]

We can see from the picture that we are interested in the point with a positive x coordinate, so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A = (\sqrt{2}, -\sqrt{2})\end{aligned}\]

For B we have

\[\begin{aligned} -4\sqrt{x} &= - \frac{2}{x}\\ x^{3/2} &= \frac{1}{2}\\ x &= \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)^{2/3} = \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}\end{aligned}\]

And so since y = -2/x we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B = \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}, -2\sqrt[3]{4} \right)\end{aligned}\]

This allows us to write the desired area as the sum of 2 integrals

\[\begin{aligned} \text{area} &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}} \left( (-x) - (-4\sqrt{x}) \right) \,dx + \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}}^{\sqrt{2}} \left( (-x) - (-\frac{2}{x}) \right) \,dx\\ &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}} \left( -x+4\sqrt {x} \right) \,dx + \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}}^{\sqrt{2}} \left( -x + \frac{2}{x} \right) \,dx\\ &= \left[ -\frac{x^2}{2} + \frac{4\cdot 2}{3} x^{3/2} \right]_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}} + \left[ -\frac{x^2}{2} + 2\ln(x) \right]_{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}}^{\sqrt{2}}\\ &= -\frac{(2^{-2/3})^2}{2} + \frac{8}{3} (2^{-2/3})^{3/2} + 0 - 0 - \frac{(\sqrt{2})^2}{2} + 2\ln(\sqrt{2}) + \frac{(2^{-2/3})^2}{2} - 2\ln(2^{-2/3})\\ &= \frac{4}{3} - 1 +\ln(2) + \frac{4}{3}\ln(2)\\ &=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{7}{3}\ln(2)\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
First, we sketch each of the three curves to see what is the region that we are talking about.

[[File:MER MATH105 April 2010 3.png|500px]]

We will need to find the coordinates of points ''A'' and ''B'' which are the intersection of curves. For ''A'' we have
:<math>\begin{align}
-x &= - \frac{2}{x}\\
x^2 &= 2\\
x &= \pm \sqrt{2}
\end{align}</math>
We can see from the picture that we are interested in the point with a positive ''x'' coordinate, so
:<math>\displaystyle
A = (\sqrt{2}, -\sqrt{2})
</math>

For ''B'' we have
:<math>\begin{align}
-4\sqrt{x} &= - \frac{2}{x}\\
x^{3/2} &= \frac{1}{2}\\
x &= \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)^{2/3} = \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}
\end{align}</math>
And so since ''y'' = -2/''x'' we have
:<math>\displaystyle
B = \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}, -2\sqrt[3]{4} \right)
</math>

This allows us to write the desired area as the sum of 2 integrals
:<math>\begin{align}
\text{area} &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}} \left( (-x) - (-4\sqrt{x}) \right) \,dx + \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}}^{\sqrt{2}} \left( (-x) - (-\frac{2}{x}) \right) \,dx\\
&= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}} \left( -x+4\sqrt {x} \right) \,dx + \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}}^{\sqrt{2}} \left( -x + \frac{2}{x} \right) \,dx\\
&= \left[ -\frac{x^2}{2} + \frac{4\cdot 2}{3} x^{3/2} \right]_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}} + \left[ -\frac{x^2}{2} + 2\ln(x) \right]_{\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{4}}}^{\sqrt{2}}\\
&= -\frac{(2^{-2/3})^2}{2} + \frac{8}{3} (2^{-2/3})^{3/2} + 0 - 0 - \frac{(\sqrt{2})^2}{2} + 2\ln(\sqrt{2}) + \frac{(2^{-2/3})^2}{2} - 2\ln(2^{-2/3})\\
&= \frac{4}{3} - 1 +\ln(2) + \frac{4}{3}\ln(2)\\
&=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{7}{3}\ln(2)
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Find the area of the region bounded by

\[\begin{aligned} y=-\frac{2}{x}, \quad y=-4\sqrt{x} \quad\text{and}\quad y=-x.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Find the area of the region bounded by 
:<math>
y=-\frac{2}{x}, \quad y=-4\sqrt{x} \quad\text{and}\quad y=-x.
</math>
